Best for what? All around versatility? Probably the spear. It’s had the longest established use on the battlefield, from Neolithic times to the Early Modern period. Arguably it’s still in use, since a bayonet turns a rifle into a hybrid short spear. You can throw a spear. You can use it for hunting. You can use it in massed formations. It has reach. Best for concealment? Knives have been around almost as long as spears, and still are carried into combat. They aren’t considered primary weapons, but for silent killing a knife is still the weapon of choice, and a really skilled person can hide it just about anywhere. Best for dueling? The sword has been a prowess weapon of the nobility since the Bronze Age. It doesn’t actually beat the Spear in terms of overall versatility and effectiveness, but swords have been around for a long time for a reason. They are versatile, have the range to be of some use against spears and put knife wielders at a disadvantage. Swords lack leverage to pierce heavy armors with a slashing attack, however. But they can pierce, unlike axes. Best for breaking armor? Pikes in the Macedonian Phalanx tradition (gave the Romans trouble). Polearms like halberds. Warhammers and axes, which have a leverage advantage over swords. Now for some comparisons Sword vs spear (spear wins)  Swords vs axes  As for armor piercing, Spear vs chain mail  Arguably the Spear hits all the high points for the “best” melee weapon in history. But at the end of the day, the decisive factor in melee combat throughout history has been conditioning, discipline, and leadership. A small, highly disciplined, army has proven time and again to be more effective than a well equipped horde of less disciplined soldiers. The Romans used swords to conquer the entire Mediterranean, thrashing highly disciplined spear and pike Phalanx armies. Focus less on the weapon and more on the combatant wielding the weapon.
